   BANDITS IN THE GLOBAL SHIPPING LANES

   PIRACY-REVIVAL-CENTERPIECE _ Piracy on the high seas has seen a
revival since the 1980s. ``Modern piracy ranges from desperate
fishermen pulling off petty larcenies at sea to highly organized
syndicates slaughtering crews to steal multimillion-dollar
vessels,'' observes the author, Jack Hitt. He tells the story of
what happened to Capt. Ken Blyth and his crew as their tanker, with
its cargo of jet fuel, headed for Vietnam. By Jack Hitt.

   (Jack Hitt is a contributing writer to the New York Times
Magazine.)

   HE JUST SAID NO _ TO THE DRUG WAR

   JOHNSON-DRUGS-CENTERPIECE _ New Mexico's iconoclastic Republican
governor, Gary Johnson, is the highest-ranking official ever to
call for partial legalization of drugs. Johnson, who admits he
smoked pot regularly when he was younger, is taking a stand many
would consider political suicide. But he is determined to pursue
the issue _ and determination is one trait that this man who runs
Ironman triathlons has in abundance. By Matthew Miller.

   (Matthew Miller, a syndicate columnist, is a senior fellow at
the Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of
Pennsylvania.)

   AUSTIN, WE HAVE A PROBLEM

   AUSTIN-GROWTH-CENTERPIECE _ Over the last decade the high-tech
economy has rolled through the laid-back capital of Texas. The
exploding growth has brought a host of urban ills _ major traffic
jams, pollution, lack of affordable housing _ to a city that
previously had a reputation as a lifestyle mecca. Now even some of
the new-money crowd is taking steps to try to restore a bit of the
old peace and quiet _ if it's not too late. By Helen Thorpe.

   (Helen Thorpe is a free-lance writer who lives in Austin. She is
currently covering the Bush campaign for George magazine.)
